input_text.content:
Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton held rallies at nearly the same time on Tuesday, with Trump doing an event in Virginia and Clinton holding one in Florida.
Trump, in a national-security focused Q&A with former Defense Intelligence Agency chief Michael Flynn, described the Iran-Iraq war in flippant terms, saying that the two countries would “fight fight fight.

We are excited for you to experience the benefits of our new software and look forward to receiving your valuable feedback. We believe that our software will redefine the way you approach project management and team collaboration. Thank you for your continued support and trust in our products and services.

results.output_text:
"The recent advancements in technology have dramatically transformed our lives. We now live in an era where technology is no longer a luxury, but a necessity. From smartphones to smart homes, artificial intelligence to augmented reality, technology has not only made our lives easier but also more efficient.

However, this proliferation of technology also raises important questions about privacy, security, and the impact on our social interactions. As we continue to integrate technology into our daily lives, it is crucial that we understand and address these concerns. 

Moreover, the digital divide continues to persist, with marginalized communities often lacking access to these technological advancements. Ensuring equal access to technology is an important step towards creating a more inclusive and equitable society.

In conclusion, while technology offers immense benefits, it is essential to navigate its challenges thoughtfully. By doing so, we can harness the full potential of technology while safeguarding our values and rights."

input_text.content:
I’m going to have a story published later today about a new document, but until then, this new interview with (and profile of) Director of National Intelligence James Clapper by the Daily Beast‘s Eli Lake is worth spending a few moments examining. Last week, Lake published one excerpt of his interview where Clapper admitted that the U.S. Government should have told the American people that the NSA was collecting their communications records: as pure a vindication of Edward Snowden’s choice as it gets, for obvious reasons. But there are several new, noteworthy revelations from this morning’s article:
Thanks to rogue contractor Edward Snowden, the machinations of the shadow bureaucracy Clapper heads have for the last eight months been exposed one news story at a time. Clapper is often the guy who has to call newspaper editors to tell them not to print stories that they usually publish anyway.
This process of pre-publication notice to the government of NSA stories has been wildly misreported in some places.

metadata.title: Inside the Mind of James Clapper
metadata.author: Glenn Greenwald

input_text.context_portion:
I’m going to have a story published later today about a new document, but until then, this new interview with (and profile of) Director of National Intelligence James Clapper by the Daily Beast‘s Eli Lake is worth spending a few moments examining. Last week, Lake published one excerpt of his interview where Clapper admitted that the U.S. Government should have told the American people that the NSA was collecting their communications records: as pure a vindication of Edward Snowden’s choice as it gets, for obvious reasons. But there are several new, noteworthy revelations from this morning’s article:
Thanks to rogue contractor Edward Snowden, the machinations of the shadow bureaucracy Clapper heads have for the last eight months been exposed one news story at a time.
input_text.completion_portion:
Clapper is often the guy who has to call newspaper editors to tell them not to print stories that they usually publish anyway.
This process of pre-publication notice to the government of NSA stories has been wildly misreported in some places.

results.output_text:
1. Clapper admits that the intelligence community has been too secretive about its operations: In a surprising admission, Clapper confesses that intelligence agencies have been too secretive about their operations, even those that are not classified. He acknowledges the need for more transparency and openness with the public to restore trust.

2. He defends the NSA's surveillance programs: Despite admitting to the need for more transparency, Clapper remains a staunch defender of the NSA's surveillance programs. He argues that they are vital for national security and insists that they have been misrepresented in the media.

3. Clapper regrets not being more upfront about the NSA's data collection: Echoing his earlier admission, Clapper expresses regret for not being more upfront with the American public about the NSA's data collection programs. He believes that the outrage and controversy could have been avoided if the public had been properly informed from the start.

4. He is critical of Edward Snowden: Clapper criticizes Snowden for leaking classified information, arguing that he has caused immense damage to national security. However, he also admits that the leaks have sparked a necessary debate about privacy and surveillance.

5. Clapper is concerned about the cyber threats: He warns about the increasing cyber threats facing the United States, identifying them as one of the top national security concerns. He calls for greater emphasis on cyber security to protect the nation's critical infrastructure. 

6. He is optimistic about the future of U.S. intelligence: Despite the challenges, Clapper remains optimistic about the future of U.S. intelligence. He believes that the intelligence community will adapt and evolve to meet the changing security landscape. 

7. Clapper plans to declassify more documents: As part of his commitment to transparency, Clapper reveals plans to declassify more documents. He hopes this will help the public better understand the work of the intelligence community and restore their trust.

These revelations provide a unique insight into Clapper's views and the current state of the U.S. intelligence community. They also highlight the ongoing debate about privacy, surveillance, and national security in the digital age.

results.output_text:
Clapper now admits that the fallout from these revelations has forced the intelligence community to become more transparent and accountable. He acknowledges that, in hindsight, the NSA should have been more upfront about its surveillance practices. He even goes as far as to say that if the intelligence community had been more transparent from the start, they may have been able to avoid the damage caused by Snowden's leaks. 

In the interview, Clapper also talks about the threat posed by ISIS and the challenges the intelligence community faces in tracking and countering the group. He acknowledges the difficulty in predicting the rise of such groups, stating that it is often only in hindsight that the signs become clear. 

The article also delves into Clapper's personal life, including his military background and how he ended up in his current role. It's a fascinating look at the man behind the headlines, and a reminder that even those in the highest positions are not immune to the consequences of their actions. 

The revelations from the interview further underscore the importance of transparency and accountability in government. As the head of the intelligence community, Clapper's admissions are significant and they open up a conversation about the need for reform in intelligence practices.

input_text.content:
Ten Indian trade unions staged one of the largest strikes in human history on Friday, with tens of millions of public sector workers participating in a shutdown of parts of the Indian economy to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s economic plans.
But if you’re an American relying on cable news, it would be hard to know it ever happened.

metadata.title: Indians Staged One of the Largest Strikes in History, But No One on U.S. Cable News Covered It
metadata.author: Zaid Jilani

results.output_text:
As a renowned chef, John knew the importance of using fresh ingredients in his dishes. He made sure to source his products from local farmers and markets, ensuring not only the best quality but also supporting the local economy. 

One day, he decided to introduce a new dish to his menu - a delightful concoction of fresh vegetables with a unique blend of spices. He started with a base of ripe, juicy tomatoes, then added crunchy bell peppers and sweet onions. He also incorporated some fresh herbs like basil and oregano, which he grew in his own garden.

After the vegetables were finely chopped, he sautéed them in a pan with some high-quality olive oil until they were soft and flavorful. Then, he added his secret blend of spices, creating a tantalizing aroma that filled the entire kitchen. 

Finally, he served the dish with a side of warm, freshly baked bread, and a glass of red wine. The dish was a hit with his customers, earning rave reviews and cementing John's reputation as a chef who knew the value of fresh, high-quality ingredients. His passion for cooking and commitment to quality were evident in every delicious bite.

results.output_text:
In the bustling city of New York, amidst the towering skyscrapers and bustling crowds, there is a hidden gem. This hidden gem is a quaint little café named 'Serendipity'. Known for its cozy ambience and delicious menu, Serendipity attracts locals and tourists alike.

The café has a charming, rustic interior with warm wooden accents and quirky vintage decor. The warm glow of fairy lights strung across the ceiling adds a magical touch to the place. The walls are adorned with a range of interesting knick-knacks and old photographs that lend a nostalgic vibe to the café.

Serendipity's menu is as delightful as its decor. From piping hot coffees to mouth-watering pastries, the café offers a wide array of treats. Their signature dish is the 'Frozen Hot Chocolate', a unique blend of rich, creamy hot chocolate and ice cream that has won the hearts of many customers.

But more than the food and decor, it's the warm and friendly service that sets Serendipity apart. The staff is always ready with a welcoming smile and they take great care to ensure that every customer feels at home.

This café has become a favorite spot for many New Yorkers who find joy in its comforting atmosphere and delectable food. Whether you're looking for a quiet corner to read a book, a cozy spot for a date, or a lively space to catch up with friends, Serendipity is the perfect place.

So, the next time you find yourself in the heart of New York, make sure to pay a visit to this charming café. It might just become your new favorite spot.

input_text.content:
The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept. The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe tread analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

metadata.title: White House Report Concludes That Bite-Mark Analysis Is Junk Science
metadata.author: Jordan Smith

input_text.context_portion: The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept.
input_text.completion_portion:
The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe tread analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

results.output_text:
The report, which has yet to be officially released, suggests that bite-mark analysis is so flawed that it should not be used in criminal trials. This controversial method of forensic investigation has been widely criticized for its lack of scientific rigor and has led to several wrongful convictions over the decades. 

The Council reportedly stated that the scientific underpinnings of bite-mark analysis are weak at best, citing the inability to accurately identify a specific individual from a bite mark on skin. They also noted the lack of standardization in the field, with different forensic odontologists often providing widely varying interpretations of the same evidence.

The report is expected to fuel ongoing debates about the validity and use of forensic science in the legal system, and could potentially lead to a reassessment of past convictions based on bite-mark evidence.

It's not the first time bite-mark analysis has come under fire. In 2009, the National Academy of Sciences issued a report calling for major reforms in the field of forensic science, singling out bite-mark analysis as particularly problematic.

The Council's report is also likely to influence future court decisions by providing a strong scientific argument against the admissibility of bite-mark evidence. It's a significant blow to a field that has long been a staple of crime scene investigations and courtroom dramas, but whose reliability has been increasingly called into question in recent years.

input_text.content:
The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept. The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe tread analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

metadata.title: White House Report Concludes That Bite-Mark Analysis Is Junk Science
metadata.author: Jordan Smith

input_text.context_portion: The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept.
input_text.completion_portion:
The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe tread analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

results.output_text:
The report states that bite-mark analysis is highly subjective, with no scientific standards for how the marks should be assessed. It suggests that the practice should be abolished in the criminal justice system due to the high risk of wrongful convictions.

The report further explains that bite-mark evidence has led to numerous wrongful convictions in the past, with some individuals spending years in prison before being exonerated through DNA evidence. The use of this type of evidence in court has been criticized by numerous scientific and legal experts who argue that it lacks a solid scientific foundation.

In fact, the report goes on to state that there is a profound lack of research into the accuracy of bite-mark analysis, as well as the factors that can affect the appearance of a bite mark on human skin. It also points out that there is considerable variability in the way different individuals' teeth can leave marks, further complicating any attempts at reliable analysis.

The council's recommendations are expected to have a significant impact on the use of forensic bite-mark evidence in the United States. It is hoped that this report will lead to a more scientifically rigorous approach to forensic evidence in general, reducing the risk of wrongful convictions and increasing the fairness and accuracy of the criminal justice system.

However, the final decision on whether to continue using bite-mark evidence rests with individual courts and jurisdictions. Some experts worry that despite the council's strong condemnation, the practice may continue in some areas due to a lack of awareness or resistance to change.

The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology is an advisory group of the nation's leading scientists and engineers who directly advise the President and the Executive Office of the President. Its role is to provide advice on a wide range of topics including improving the quality of life for Americans, stimulating the economy, and promoting American competitiveness in the global marketplace.

Complete the following text: {text}

input_text.content: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations. Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt, most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

metadata.title: The Unrelenting Pundit-Led Effort to Delegitimize All Negative Reporting About Hillary Clinton
metadata.author: Glenn Greenwald

input_text.context_portion: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations.
input_text.completion_portion: Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt, most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

results.output_text:
Krugman stated that he believes these investigations, while important in maintaining transparency and accountability, have been disproportionately focused on the Democratic nominee, often to the point of undermining their credibility and reputation. He argued that the media's obsessive scrutiny of every detail of the nominee's life and career threatens to obstruct the public's perception of their policy plans, achievements, and qualifications for the presidency.

He went on to criticize the media's tendency to present a false equivalency, treating minor missteps by the Democratic nominee as on par with major scandals involving their Republican counterparts. According to Krugman, this approach not only distorts the reality of each candidate's fitness for office, but also contributes to a cynical public attitude towards politics in general.

While acknowledging that no candidate should be immune from scrutiny, Krugman emphasized the need for balanced, fair reporting. He pointed out that the relentless negative coverage of the Democratic nominee, often based on unverified rumors or out-of-context facts, is not just unfair but also detrimental to the democratic process.

In conclusion, Krugman defended the Democratic nominee, urging journalists to focus on substantive issues and policy debates, rather than getting carried away with sensationalistic and misleading narratives. He warned that the media's obsession with scandal and controversy, if left unchecked, could seriously undermine the public's trust in our democratic institutions.
results.prompt_string: Complete the following text: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations.

input_text.content: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations. Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt, most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

metadata.title: The Unrelenting Pundit-Led Effort to Delegitimize All Negative Reporting About Hillary Clinton
metadata.author: Glenn Greenwald

input_text.context_portion: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations.
input_text.completion_portion: Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt, most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

results.output_text:
Krugman, a respected economist and a stalwart liberal, argued that the media's focus on the Democratic nominee's alleged wrongdoing was misplaced. He pointed out that journalists, in their quest for neutrality, often fall into the trap of false equivalency - portraying both sides as equally flawed, even when the evidence suggests otherwise.

He asserted that the Democratic nominee, despite being subjected to relentless scrutiny and numerous investigations, had been found guilty of no significant wrongdoing. Krugman criticized the media's relentless focus on alleged scandals, arguing that it distracted from the real issues at stake in the election.

Krugman also took issue with the notion that the Democratic nominee was inherently untrustworthy. He argued that this perception was largely a result of decades of partisan attacks, rather than any substantive evidence of wrongdoing. He defended the nominee's record, pointing to their accomplishments in public service and their detailed policy proposals.

In his column, Krugman made it clear that he believed the media was failing in its duty to inform the public. He argued that by focusing on sensationalist stories and alleged scandals, journalists were obscuring the real choice facing voters in the election. 

In conclusion, Krugman's piece was a robust defense of the Democratic nominee and a critique of the current state of journalism. Whether one agrees or disagrees with his position, it is clear that Krugman is unafraid to challenge conventional wisdom and speak his mind.
